ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Real-world project research and presentation. How to conduct stakeholder interviews. How to cope with extreme jet lag.
Gulf Security Capstone: Incredible course! It has been a whirlwind of deep learning, surreal and incredible travel, and professional training.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: extremely relevant topic at the frontier of knowledge
Weaknesses: was vastly underprepared for the subject matter coming into the course

Gulf Security Capstone: I had an amazing time in my capstone and learned so much! No weaknesses. 
Capstone Program: I'm happy I was in this capstone! The other options looked not nearly as interesting--all data and coding. It's a real lottery. Jackson needs to realize that we're not all quantitative students. Some of us are actually interested in global affairs.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would! (Assuming Roland teaches this Capstone again, though it's not exactly a "repeatable" project).

Yes! I would absolutely recommend Roland as a capstone advisor! He is truly interested in expanding your mind, exposing you to real policy and diplomacy, and allowing you to make a real difference in the world. He strikes the perfect balance between offering guidance and refraining from micromanagement.

extras.title: GLBL 499 02 - Gulf Security for a New Era
